After finishing this Algorithms Course, and I decided it would be cool to put some of my newly acquired skills to the test, while also learning about web development, so I created Algorithm Visualiser. It is an interactive site where you can, as the name implies, see how some algorithms work. <!–-break-–>

The interface is made up of a board (this is where the action happens) and some options (on the left). To run an algorithm, just hover over the Algorithms tab and pick one. The astute among you might figure out that running BFS ten times on the same, empty board yields the same path, so let’s modify the board! A cell can have four values:

  • the green, start cell (the algorithm starts here)
  • the red, destination cell (the algorithm tries to reach this cell)
  • empty (nothing to see here)
  • wall (a path cannot go through a wall)
  • light (algorithms that take weights into consideration will prefer these cells to empty or heavy ones)
  • heavy (algorithms that take weights into consideration will try light or empty cells before checking these)

By default, all the cells are empty. To add walls, click a cell or drag over the board. Cells should turn darker. To add light cells, while pressing L, click a cell and an feather icon should appear. Similarly for heavy ones, but you should press H. The start and destination cell can be changed using the buttons on the left.
